block.p: Youth of America, heed this word:
Downsizing.
It is the word of the future. Remember it: Downsizing.
Youth of America, heed this word:
Downsizing.
It is the word of the future. Remember it: Downsizing.
Say it three times: "Downsizing. Downsizing. Downsizing."
Now it will stay with you.

Holding it firmly in mind -- say it once again for good measure -- "Downsizing" -- that's the way to hold it firmly in mind -- now holding it firmly in mind, study its verbal and adjectival offshoots.
These are downsized and -- are you ready for this? -- downsized.
Yes, both the verb and adjective are the same: downsized.
Illustrations:
Verb form: Consolidated has downsized again.
Adjective form: See the downsized 49-year-old man.
"Heavens!" you cry. "Has that 49-year-old man been shrunk like a fine woolen sweater washed in boiling water?"
No, he has not been shrunk. He has been laid off from work. We no longer say "laid off." We now say "downsized."
You naturally ask:
"Does it follow then that Consolidated, having downsized again, has also been laid off and, therefore, no longer produces its magnificent consolidations?"
Not at all. Here is something that is fun to say: Lean and mean.
Say it a few times to feel the delightful yet muscular humor of it.
"Lean and mean. Lean and mean. Lean and so on."
Good. Now the downsizing that occurred when Consolidated downsized not only produced that 49-year-old downsized man you saw, but it also rendered the company lean and mean.

As we have seen, "lean and mean" is delightful to say, and saying pleasant things puts people in pleasant moods. When Wall Street people are in a pleasant mood they invest in things that have made them feel pleasant.
In our hypothetical case, the source of Wall Street's happy mood is Consolidated, whose downsizing has given investors the pleasant opportunity to say "lean and mean."
Result?
Up goes Consolidated's stock.
In short, Consolidated upsizes by downsizing.
Youth of America, you stand today on the threshold of (insert any one of 12,000 commencement speeches to be made this month).
Naturally then, you are worried about your future. Does it make sense, you ask, to go to work for a great company like Consolidated?
It does not. Think:
If an employer's continued upsizing requires continued downsizing, why would a logical person wish to work for him?
The reason is obvious: Because that person wants to become the first illustration in a primer on economics which begins:
"Look, children, look. Look and see the downsized 49-year-old man."

Where, then, shall the youth of America look for work that will help them realize the traditional American yearning for food, clothing, shelter and a better life for their offspring than their own downsized existence?
Many of you will say, "Dealing drugs. That's where it's at."
Wrong. The pressures are murderous. Colombia downsizes even more completely than Consolidated.
Heed these words, youth:
Old people.
America is producing old people at a prodigious rate, and things they cannot do are beyond belief. Youth's future lies in doing modern things that defeat the old.
Idea 1: A business that not only installs VCR's for old people, but also programs them weekly to record favorite shows. At present nobody over age 22 can perform either task.

Idea 2: An opening service for the millions defeated every day in the struggle to open modern packaging and containers. Like home-delivery pizza service, a phone call would bring highly skilled openers speeding to help incompetent old-timers.
Thousands of similar opportunities for youth to profit from the incompetence of the aged will become apparent. Bill Gates, richest man in the universe, started this way: small.
Should you be successful, who knows? You may end up downsizing and know the joy of leanness, meanness and spondulicks galore.
